solution:
Only the $8$ corners of the cube have three faces painted red. Each edge has one cube that has $2$ faces painted red. There are $12$ edges, so $12$ cubes have $2$ faces painted red. Each of the six faces has only the center cube painted on exactly $1$ face, and the single cube in the center of the three-inch cube is the only one with no faces painted. We can thus produce the following table: $$
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Number of red faces} & \textbf{Number of one-inch cubes} \\
\hline
\ast3 & 8 \\
\hline
\ast2 & 12 \\
\hline
1 & 6 \\
\hline
0 & 1 \\
\hline
\multicolumn{2}{|r|}{
\text{Total = 27}}\\
\hline
\end{array}
$$$\ast$ Number of cubes with $2$ or $3$ red faces is $8 + 12 = \boxed{20}.$
socratic_questions:
1. Can you describe how the cube was cut into one-inch cubes? How many sub-cubes did it produce?
2. How many faces did each sub-cube have? How many of those faces were painted red?
3. How many sub-cubes have exactly three faces painted red? Can you explain why?
4. How many sub-cubes have exactly two faces painted red? Can you explain why?
5. How many sub-cubes have only one face painted red? Can you describe their positions?
6. How many sub-cubes have no faces painted red? Can you describe their positions?
7. Can you create a table to summarize the number of sub-cubes according to the number of red faces?
8. How can you calculate the total number of sub-cubes with at least two red faces?
9. Can you verify that the total number of sub-cubes matches the result obtained in step 8?
